Award.AwardTitle: The evolution of honest communication: the physiological consequences of social costs
Award.AbstractNarration:
The honesty of animal communication systems is a central issue in behavioral biology. What prevents weak, low quality individuals from "cheating" by signaling that they are strong? The general answer is that quality signals are costly and signaling a high level of quality is relatively more costly for low quality than high quality individuals. This project will take a new perspective on the factors that maintain signal honesty by testing the interplay between two well-known costs: aggressive social costs and physiological costs. The short and long term consequences of signal inaccuracy will be tested via behavioral observation and measurement of endocrine titers in Polistes dominulus paper wasps.

Intellectual merit: Although much progress has been made toward understanding the honesty of animal communication systems, many well-known ornaments lack clear costs. Further, there are theoretical and empirical challenges associated with understanding how aggressive social costs maintain signal honesty over evolutionary time. Our proposal will extend and re-define current hypotheses by testing the physiological consequences of social punishment. As such, it will address many of the challenges associated with understanding social costs and broaden the applicability of this hypothesis to diverse systems. Overall, understanding the dynamic feedbacks between physiology and social costs should increase understanding of the reliability of animal communication systems.

Broader impacts: Training of undergraduate students will be a major component of the project, as this research is effective at capturing student interest and the techniques are accessible to aspiring researchers. Additional educational activities will include participation in public science education programs and visits to local schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many animals have signals that communicate information about their strength to other animals. Signals of strength are useful because they allow animals to rapidly assess the abilities of rivals, thereby minimizing conflict and stabilizing social interactions. Dishonest signaling seems intuitively advantageous because a weak animal who signals strength could win contests or deter rivals. Nevertheless, animals typically communicate their abilities honestly. What prevents weak animals from dishonestly signaling that they are strong? Theory suggests that animals are honest because signaling strength is difficult or ‘costly’ so only the best individuals can afford to signal strength. However, in many cases, there have been challenges identify the costs that maintain signal accuracy. We provided a new perspective on honest communication by showing that animals with dishonest signals are aggressively punished and this punishment has lasting effects on the hormones of the dishonest signaler and those they interact with. The hormonal effects of dishonesty are particularly interesting because hormones influence an animal’s behavior, appearance, and internal function. As a result, animals are favored to communicate their strength honestly because dishonesty has diverse and lasting consequences via effects on both hormones and behavior.

The project also addressed other questions in the area of social signaling and hormones. 1) We examined how the social environment influences hormones in paper wasps, focusing on the hormone ‘juvenile hormone’. We found that both behavior during a contest and social environment influence hormone levels. These results are interesting because they contribute to the growing evidence that insect hormones are just as flexible and responsive to the social environment as vertebrate hormones. 2) We measured how juvenile influences an individual’s behavior, finding that weak individual with increased juvenile hormone act as if they are strong. 3) We measured the relationship between signals of strength and success in the wild, finding that wasps who signal strength have higher survival, reproductive success, and dominance rank. Therefore, signals of strength provide good information about an individual’s overall abilities. These results also suggest that signals of strength provide real benefits in the wild, so costs of dishonesty are likely to be an important counterbalancing mechanism that prevents dishonesty. 4) We measured the relationship between visual signals and eyes across many wasp species, finding  wasps who communicate with visual signals have better vision than wasps that do not use visual signals. Therefore, communication influences the evolution of sensory abilities.  

The project provided exposure to science and technology for young people and members of the public via: 1) outreach to students at local schools, 2) media coverage, including an article written for Scientific American, and 3) training of 4 graduate students and 25 undergraduate students. Students included members of groups traditionally underrepresented in science. Seven of the undergraduate researchers involved in this project have gone on to attend graduate school in biology.
